description.text: This was cut out of a 12" x 12" piece of 1/8th inch acrylic.
Laser it! Set it to just vectors so you don't raster the letters.

The objective for this project was to create an object to vector cut from acrylic. I decided to create a simple monogram using my first initial and a swirly background pattern in Adobe Illustrator. The design measures 3 and 1/8" in diameter and was printed on black acrylic.
This project was created with a 40 watt Epilog Engraver; the raster engraving was set at 100% speed and 50% power and the vector cutting was set to 12% speed, 100% power, and 5000 Hz frequency.

title: MK7 Filament Guide for John Watson's Aluminum Extruder Upgrade

description.text: I purchased John Watson's Aluminum Extruder Upgrade (http://www.wotz101.com/wotzbotz/index.html) in the hopes of resolving all of my extrusion issues. After receiving the upgrade, I was pleased with its simplicity and utility however, the skipped steps problem didn't immediately disappear. Upon closer inspection, I was noticing that the filament was constantly getting pulled off of the drive gear by some unknown force (and still unknown, may be a characteristic of my particular printer, not sure). I was not able to see this with the other extruder mods I had, so having the even more minimalistic extruder helped out a lot! In order to remedy the issue, I decided to create a filament guide which is compatible with the aluminum extruder mod. After installing this mod, I haven't skipped a step yet!

NOTE: I have only tested this on my Replicator 1 Dual (MK7 extruders) and cannot guarantee that it will fit on an MK8+ extruder. Material: ABS preferred but mine is PLA (I didn't have any ABS on-hand but due to the temperature of this zone I would highly recommend ABS!)
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Fill: 15%
Extra Perimeters: 1 Step 1: Print off the guides for your printer, a plated STL is available for dual extruder Rep1s.
Step 2: Remove the fans/heatsinks from the extruder assembly and place the printed parts as shown in the photo. It should be a loose fit so that it doesn't interfere with extrusion. The pressure of the heatsink against the motor will keep it in place when you screw it all back together.
Step 3: Re-assemble the fans and screw them onto the extruder assemble.
Step 4: Re-load filament and print on!

A pair of measuring cups on a stick.
Coose yor volumes. Originally made for measuring cornstarch for oogoo rubber.
But equally good for coffee powder or anything else.

Eiter use the common decimal fractions (in cubic mm):
An example sequence:
(100,500);-(200,1k)-;-(500,2k)-;-(1k,5k)-;(2k,10k);(5k,20k) Or use powers of three.
With those you need the least number of measuring cups but calculating exact volumes gets cumbersome. Good for ratios though.
A suggested base size sequence in cubic mm:
(10,30);(90,270); -(810,2430)- ;(7290,21870)
Or maybe better:
(30,90); (270,810) ; -(2430,7290)- Better make the stick a little too long than a little too short.

description.text:
This is a modification for the Prusa i3. I designed a new Z Axis to work with the Y and X from the official Prusa i3 git sources. I am currently using this on my custom printer, with my current setup I have a Z height of 260mm. *Update**
I've uploaded a v2 with better support for the Z smooth rod, and added a hook to make attaching to the Y bed easier. I also made the Z top wider and added holes to attach a zmax end stop

**BOM
The same as for a normal i3 just none of the parts need for the Z. **Full Printer
The X and Y axis is straight from git://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3.git Print out the parts for the X and Y following the normal directions. **My mod's
Print two of each of the stl files. ** Z-Axis.stl
You will need at least 115mm in Z height to be able to print these, you can edit the config.scad files and shorten the var 'arm_length', but you will lose X build volume by doing so. Once printed they are pretty straight forward to install. I included a pic that should help with most questions. The picture is of the first prototypes I printed the arms were a little short dropped my x build to 150mm instead of the normal 200mm, redesigned to get the full 200mm **Z-Axis-Top.stl
These will print just fine on any printer. Once printed just place them on the top of the Z smooth rods and connect with a threaded rod, 8mm or 5/8 inch should work fine. ** Once assembled my current build volume is 200x200x260

• Print with at least 25% infill.

  • Drill out the holes in the lid to 3mm. Use four M3-screws to close the case. If needed, drill the holes in the case bottom to 2.8mm, or use a different type of screw, e.g. a self tapping screw.

author: odie_wan

title: InMoov finger prosthetic project
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since InMoov hand has been released on Thingiverse, I receive demands on how to use it as a prosthetic. Lately a french FabLab asked me if they could use InMoov for their project. I knew the initial design was not adapted for that matter and I think it could be better done if I kept the prosthetic perspective in mind.
So this research can be used for the Bionico Prosthetic project or any other prosthetic project as long as it is not with commercial uses.
The goal is to keep all motors within the palm and to create mechanicaly actuated fingers. You can follow InMoov Robot project here:
http://inmoov.blogspot.com
You can follow more:
http://www.inmoov.fr/inmoov2-hand-progress/

This finger has two types of motors, make sure to download the correct casing and FingerWorm for your purpose.
This is meant to be assembled using a servo motor Corona DS238HV or a DC brushless motor with planetary reduction 154:1
from Pololu.
The motor used:
http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1109
The driver used
http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/2130 With the servo Corona DS238HV use these files:
-FingerWormV1.stl
-ServoHolderV2.stl
-PhalangeV6.stl
-ActuatorsV3.stl With the planetary gear motor use these files:
-FingerWormV2.stl
-MotorHolderV3mid.stl
-MotorHolderV3top.stl
-PhalangeV6.stl
-ActuatorsV3.stl Update 18/07/13 PhalangeV1 is now PhalangeV2.
Update 20/07/13 PhalangeV2 to PhalangeV3.
Update 23/07/13 PhalangeV3 to PhalangeV4, ActuatorV1 to ActuatorV2
Update 24/07/13 PhalangeV4 to PhalangeV5
Update 25/07/13 ServoHolderV1 to ServoHolderV2 to get more flex on the finger
Update 13/08/13 PhalangeV5 to PhalangeV6 for even better flex. Added MotorHolderV3mid and MotorHolderV3mid for the planetary gear motor.. Added FingerWormV2 for the planetary gear motor. There is no instructions yet, as this is a work in progress.

With two of these you can mount umbrellas with a cylindrical main shafts onto your balcony railing. The railing has two have two or more horizontal rectangular bars whichs inside edges line up vertically. Rubber inlets prevents the holders from slipping sidewards and ledges prevent them from slipping downwards. To mount an umberlla: First put one holder on the topmost rectangular bar where you like it. Fixate it with two velcro-tapes. Then mount a second holder directly below the first one onto the lowest rectangular bar. Finally slide your umbrella in and fixate the hight with the hex bolts and wing nuts. An added set of simple size adapters can make this work for a wide diameter range. Features:
  • holds steady as rock
  • simply removable
  • simply adjustable
  • non scratching
    • First posted here:
    http://www.quirky.com/ideations/510894

You'll need:
  • Two M6 (or your choice) hex head screws and two winged nuts.
  • Four velcro strips long enough for your railings circumference and 21mm (or your choice) wide.
  • 3mm or thicker sheet of rubber
    • Then:
  • Adjust two holders to your needs & print them.
  • Cut rectangular rubber sheets and glue them into the indents
  • Strap the holders onto the railings with the velcro tapes slide in the umprella and fixate the height the screws.

title: Idler Pulley Conversion - 608 ZZ Bearing Cobblebot

description.text:
I had some bearings leftover from my Cobblebot build and other spare parts. I needed a few Idler pullies for a belt system I was working on so I designed this conversion kit. 
The 2 outer pieces press fit onto the outside of the bearings and each other to create flanges for a GT2 Timing belt to rest in. There is a 7mm gap between the 2 flanges. By scaling the Z axis this could work for other width belts. 
The 2 inner pieces press fit onto the inside of the bearings and each other to create a centered screw hole for an M5 Screw. These 2 pieces also ensure that there is no binding by created a gap between the bearing and any fasteners you use. 
An additional set of 2 inner pieces can be used as a spacer if you need the idler to sit father from whatever it is resting on. 
Be warned all of these are intended to be a very tight fit. I used 0.1mm gap and 0.2mm gap so that the parts would not slide when in use. I assembled mine by hand but you may need a vice or pliers to get everything together. If your printer is not producing mostly round circle or over extruding you might need to clean up the parts to get everything to fit.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes: Many of the parts are using a multiple of 0.2mm so I would recommend that layer height. You will get one layer in some places and 2 laters in others. Additionally, The smallest wall is 0.49mm and my slicer only wanted to draw it with a 0.4mm extrusion width. If you are seeing strange behavior with the smaller part that's probably the explanation. You shouldn't need support or a raft.

title: Prusa i3 spool holder laser cut.

description.text:
This is an add-on spool bracket for the Prusa i3 laser cut series of frames. Teh key feature is 608 bearings for the ends are captured in slots that allow for easy spool changes and minimal friction.  
Cut from whatever material you feel like. It only needs to be thicker than 3.5mm and I used plywood about 5.3mm.

comments.text: What thickness of wood or metal should this be laser cut from?
comments.author: ipblythe

comments.text:
Totally doesn't matter what thickness. Ideally 5mm or more. A 608 bearing is 8x22x7mm so the only number that matters is 7mm wide. The main arm and one of the caps forms the pocket the 608 bearing drops into.
So that means as long as the material is thicker than 3.5mm you are good to go. 3.5mm is a bit thin for the arms being you want them semi rigid.
comments.author: ipblythe

author: Unknown

description.text: I have moved, checkout this design at https://www.youmagine.com/designs/d-d-props-collection It's a simple storage crate. For tabletop D&D. Print a whole bunch and you can make nice storage rooms. But, it's a storage crate OF DOOM. This infernal crate will refuse to print correctly every single time. Not because it's a bad STL, not because it's complex to print. But because it's cursed. As you can see on the photo, I have quite a lot of these, but they are all bad prints. Half of them miss the bottom layer because it broke off. And some have holes, and even one of them managed to tip itself over during printing.

Just don't print it. Just DON'T.
If you do want to print it, I recommend being close to mount Doom with a hobbit. If a fully printed crate starts to whisper at you, give it to the hobbit and send him to mount Doom. Tell him to throw in the cube. When the hobbit returns, shoot him (because you can never be too sure)

title: Replacement Handle for Swiffer Wet Jet

description.text:
We use the Swiffer Wet Jet in our house. A lot. Like, two crazy dogs and two messy kids “a lot”. They’re great, convenient tools, but the design of the handle leaves a lot to be desired. For example, you should be able to use it for more than a few weeks without snapping the handle in half. Call me crazy, but I think that should be a main focus of their product design. Unfortunately, every Swiffer I’ve used has the same flaw… thin plastic where the shaft meets the handle. Rather than go out and donate another $20 to Swiffer, and needlessly add yet another broken handled mop to the dump, I decided to just print my own, sturdier handle. The handle I’ve put together is very strong, and allows you to apply significant pressure to the cleaning pad. There are really only three parts to print:
  • Handle 1
  • Handle 2
  • Trigger
    • The pieces are held together with glue. I used Gorilla Glue Gel. You’ll need three bolts (and nuts) to attach it to the Swiffer shaft.
  • I used 3x #6 pan head machine screws of varying lengths.
    • Assembly depends on the current state of your Swiffer. If you’re considering doing this, you either don’t care about the handle, or you are looking at a broken handle anyway, so: NOTE: You’ll want to be careful not to break the wire, or the existing switch. This design uses that switch and wire! It’s possible to replace, or rewire this, but that seems like more work than I was willing to do. Be careful! Step 1: Remove the old handle. There is one screw on the bottom of the handle, and another hidden under the button. The one under the button isn’t easy to get to. You either need to pry off the button somehow, or otherwise break it apart. I used a flat head screwdriver to encourage the pieces apart. Step 2: Print the three parts you’ll need. Again, the parts you’ll need are Handle 1, Handle 2, and the Trigger. Step 2b: Prep the parts? The tolerances on this are pretty tight. I wanted to make sure the handle fit as snugly as possible. Depending on how your printer is calibrated, you might not be able to get both halves to fit tightly together. You may have to sand the inner opening for the shaft a bit to get things to fit cleanly. Try to do this before you glue anything. Step 3: Place one half of the handle assembly on the shaft, taking notice of where the holes line up for the bolts. The Swiffer shaft has larger holes on one side than the other, and the handle should match. Step 4: Route the wiring for the switch. It should be hanging through he opening. We’re going to glue the parts together BEFORE shoving the switch in place. Step 5: I strongly recommend test fitting at this point. Make sure the two halves of the handle are completely touching each other with no gaps. Ensure that the switch wire is not being pinched between the two halves of the assembly. Sand/drill/adjust as necessary, making sure to repeat steps 3 and 4 each time. Once everything is fitting nicely together: Step 6: Glue the two halves together. No going back now! This part is pretty straightforward… With one half of the handle already in place on the Swiffer shaft, line up and glue the two halves together. A good guide is to make sure that the bolt holes line up, and that the back is flush. If you were careful and persistent with the prep in step 5, then this should be pretty easy. ** be sure to only glue the outside edges of the two halves! If you get glue on the shaft, it’s going to be stuck completely and you can’t rotate or remove the handle if necessary. Step 7: Insert the trigger into the trigger opening with the flat side facing the switch, and use a bolt to secure it in place. I think I used a 1” bolt. Step 8: Clean your floors! Possible improvements:
  • The trigger tends to rest nicely against the switch, but there’s no spring or anything holding it in place. I may design a version of the trigger with some spring to it to keep it pressed against the switch.
  • The bolts could be recessed… I don’t know… It’s really solid right now, and I don’t know if it’s worth it.
  • There could be a hanging loop on the back. We don’t hang our kitchen cleaning tools, but I do see where that could be beneficial to some.

Printer:

Monoprice Dual Extrusion

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used .20.

Infill:

30%

Notes: The tolerances on this are really... really tight. Your mileage might vary. I'm also not sure if the shaft they use is uniform from one swiffer to the next. Just prepare yourself emotionally for the possibility of some light sanding.

This is a 3d model of a Securitron from Fallout New Vegas. Credit for the model goes here: https://grabcad.com/library/fallout-new-vegas-securitron-1 I edited the solid model to enlarge the face on the screen, remove some features that were too small to print, and hollow out the back to save some material. I hollowed it out with a large radius (ends of curves nearly touching), so it should print without support material. The model is split in 2 so that it can be printed in 2 halves. I cut the wheel flat on the bottom so the model can stand on its own once printed (Even printing just the front half works). There is also a large cavity in the wheel so it can be put on a stand or some weight can be put in there for stability. There is a Yes Man design with the face engraved into the screen, and one with a blank screen (face could be painted on). The other faces are on here as images in case anyone needs them, but I could not trace them into a good looking shape because of their level of detail. Yes Man's face is just a smiley so it looks fine. I'm sure people would love a remix if anyone is more talented than I am with layered graphics. (As a side note, Yes Man actually has claw hands, but all other securitrons have gun hands. I left the gun hands on the model because the claws would be harder to print and would not fit for the standard securitrons, which there are 3 of). The model is somewhere around 6 inches tall, but it scales well. I printed a 3" one without any issue, but haven't printed one full sized yet. If you have any reasonable requests, I can fairly easily modify the model, or send the solid model. Update: An armless version was created so that flexible tubes could be inserted into the body and hands to allow movable arms.

Printer:

Da Vinci Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

5%

Notes: I printed one at 0.3 layer height and 5% infill. I would recommend a smaller layer height to improve the quality of the curves on the arms and torso. A print at 0.15 was much smoother, whereas the 0.3 print had visible stepping. This was also shrunk down to half size. I did not need to use supports, but if you wanted to use them it wouldn't hurt anything. My printer crosses gaps well (and this is a small gap due to the radius on the cavity) so I decided not to use supports and it worked out well.
Post Printing As with any model, a good filing of rough edges and an acetone bath prior to paint will really make it look great.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 spool holder laser cut.

description.text: The cones hold the spool onto a 5/16 (or 8mm) threaded rod and adjust to different sized spool holes. The cones can be easily removed to allow the spool to be taken off. Springs pushing a plunger into the larger end of the cones retain them.

Print two cones and two washers. If you want you can use two nuts to retain one of the cones but I made mine so both have springs. The rod is 5/16 with two 608 bearings with a nut holding it on both sides on each end. The rod and bearing just drop into place in the wood bracket. The opening on the bracket is away from the printer and at an angle to keep the rod from falling out. The cones can be put on and taken off without taking anything off the rod by just pushing back on the spring. The cones have a slot that allows them to be taken on and off. Just pull the rod out the back side of the holder, pull the cones apart and slid one cone off. Slide the spool onto the rod then put the cone back on. The spring and plunger push into the cone and hold it on. Part http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:118049 was used to hold the rod onto my Prusa I3 (custom top frame). Videos:
http://youtu.be/olPRlIk4npY
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JlwgfdYHBzU

This is a simple thumbnut for nylock-type friction action.

I made this for the adjustable bed on my printrbot GO, but it is scalable for a variety of uses.  
You can customize the height, diameter, internal diameter, height of the knurled portion and number of knurls and includes a nopheads polyholes module for properly sized internal diameter but with an adjustment (85%) so that you can run a tap through the hole to cut threads.  I found that when I printed them in Taulman 618 nylon that i could also just force them into the threaded rod without cutting threads for an even tighter fit.

This design replaces the stock mendel-parts.com Orca v0.20 Y belt end pulleys with pivoting ones which allow the belt tension to be adjusted by tightening a M4 threaded rod running under the ZY structure. The advantage is twofold:
  • The belt tightness can be easily adjusted by turning the nuts in the M4 rod.
  • The rod compensates for the belt tension so that the belt tension no longer acts to bend the left M8 threaded rod. Otherwise tightening the Y belt may result in the Y rails becoming non-parallel and causing problems in levelling the print bed.
    • Note: decreases the Z print area by a couple of millimeters, in my machine to 120mm.

Print front and back pieces. Install back piece and tighten it to the aluminum plate. Install front piece but leave that one loose. Install and tighten the belt to a tightness somewhat less than the final tightness. Install a 350mm long M4 rod between the pieces and tighten until the front piece has pivoted to give the belt a desired tightness.

This filament holder aligned the filament to the slot so that least string bending would incur before the filament feed into the extruder. It would fit filament holders of width of less than 74mm. The filament could be held in two ways. With one pin going through the spool hole and held by Part 3 or with two pins and four bearing serves as bottom rolling wheels and hold the spool. To install the hinge pin and ball bearing wheel: Put two ball bearing into one hinge pin. Push the hinge pin and ball bearing into one hole. The hinge pins cap facing your self. Push the other ball bearing into another hole. The hinge pin should now rotate freely and sits nicely inside the ball bearing. Repeat for the other hinge pin and two ball bearings. The hinge pins and ball bearing wheels can be purchased here: http://www.lowes.com/pd_308895-1277-S841-563___?productId=4767377&pl=1&Ntt=0308895 http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010GI2ZCG?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00 Use super glue to glue Part 1 and 3. Use M6 Screw to screw down Part 1 and 2 thru the slot and secure the whole filament holder. You can use the Part 1 and Part 2 only for 1Kg spool, but for thin spool, such as the 300g spool came included with Robo3D, the spool could fall down. You need to print Part 2 to block both sides. This spool holder is smooth compared to many other holders I printed before and I like it. That's why I am sharing with other Robo3D users.
